The only caveat to this advice is to be certain that you keep the
internal =
state of the object valid at all times.

Do you have a lot of code in your =
constructor because of complex
internal relationships between the attribute=
s?

If you can move code out of your constructor without risking internal
v=
alidity, then I would certainly recommend it.

Simon

>Subject: Re: [junit] Testing constructors

>
>IMHO, construc=
tors ought to just construct an object to a sane 
>state, anything
>else sh=
ould be external to the constructor.  So, initially I 
>would take a lot
>o=
f the 'functionality' and computation out of the constructor 
>if possible.=
 
>Once the object is constructed, you should be able to test its 
>state. =
 If not,
>there's a code smell there.  So, I would suggest that you take 
>=
what you can out
>of the ctor, construct the object to its known/sane state=
, 
>then test against
>that.
>
>HTH.
>-jason
